questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neglect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

questions.text: A child presents with bone pain and hepatosplenomegaly. A trephine biopsy and aspirate show the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme deficient in this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical vignette of a child with bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and trephine biopsy showing a cell with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance points to diagnosis of Gaucher's disease, in which enzyme deficient is glucocerebrosidase (also known as beta-glucosidase).

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A case of complete gonadal dysgenesis was observed in a 46XY individual with female characteristics. The origin of complete gonadal dysgenesis lies in alterations of the SRY gene. What leads to complete gonadal dysgenesis in the SRY gene? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Deletion of gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complete gonadal dysgenesis in a 46XY individual is primarily caused by the deletion of the SRY gene, which leads to a failure in the development of male gonads, resulting in female characteristics.

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased fibrinogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In DIC, one typically sees a constellation of laboratory findings including decreased fibrinogen, increased PT and aPTT, elevated FDPs, and the presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. These changes reflect both the excessive activation of the coagulation cascade and the secondary activation of fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the consumption of clotting factors and secondary bleeding complications.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Hematology/Coagulation disorders

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal canula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.  30%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered by nasal cannula increases by approximately 4% for every 1 liter per minute of oxygen flow. Thus:
  • • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%. 2 L/min would be about 28%. 3 L/min would be about 32%.
  • • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%.
  • • 2 L/min would be about 28%.
  • • 3 L/min would be about 32%.
  • • Given the options provided, the closest and most commonly accepted approximation for the FiO2 being delivered at a flow rate of 3 L/min through a nasal cannula would be around 30%.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 25%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 1 L/min via nasal cannula.
  • • Option A. 25%:
  • • Option C. 40%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 5 L/min via nasal cannula.
  • • Option C. 40%:
  • • Option D. 45%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 6 L/min via nasal cannula.
  • • Option D. 45%:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The FiO2 delivered by a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min is approximately 30%.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prodrug? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Primidone is not a prodrug because it is pharmacologically active in its original form, although it also produces active metabolites. Prodrugs like Proguanil, Sulindac, and 5-Fluorouracil require metabolic activation to exert their therapeutic effects.

questions.text: Which of the following represents maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Platelet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maximum amplitude in Thromboelastography represents platelets. TEG is a non-invasive test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with no significant past medical history is scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the preoperative discussion, the anesthesiologist explains the plan for anesthesia induction, emphasizing the importance of a rapid onset with smooth, controlled sedation. The patient expresses concern about feeling nauseous after waking up, and the anesthesiologist mentions using an agent that minimizes such risks and ensures a quick recovery. Which of the following agents is commonly used for intravenous induction of anesthesia in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Propofol is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent commonly used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. It has a rapid onset of action, usually within 30 seconds, and provides a smooth, rapid recovery, making it highly effective for outpatient and short surgical procedures. Propofol is known for its antiemetic properties, reducing postoperative nausea and vomiting, and is often preferred for patients concerned about these side effects. However, it can cause dose-dependent hypotension and respiratory depression, requiring careful monitoring during administration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Etomidate : Etomidate is another intravenous induction agent known for its minimal cardiovascular effects, making it suitable for patients with compromised cardiac function. However, it is not typically used as the first-line agent due to its association with adrenal suppression and increased risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting, unlike propofol.
  • • Option A. Etomidate
  • • Option B. Ketamine : Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that provides analgesia, sedation, and amnesia with minimal respiratory depression. It is particularly useful in trauma patients or those with risk of hypotension, but it is not commonly used for routine anesthesia induction due to its psychomimetic effects, such as vivid dreams and hallucinations during recovery.
  • • Option B. Ketamine
  • • Option D. Midazolam : Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used primarily for premedication and procedural sedation, not as a primary induction agent. It has anxiolytic, amnesic, and sedative properties but lacks the rapid onset and recovery profile of propofol, making it unsuitable for the induction of general anesthesia.
  • • Option D. Midazolam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propofol is widely used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia due to its rapid onset, smooth induction, and quick recovery profile. It minimizes postoperative nausea and vomiting, though it requires careful monitoring for potential hypotension and respiratory depression. Other agents like etomidate, ketamine, and midazolam have specific uses but do not match propofol's overall safety and efficacy for routine induction.

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition. Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV
  • ➤ When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition.
  • ➤ Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but his respiratory rate is 26/min. Room air Sp02 is 86%. He is administered oxygen through a non -rebreathing mask with a flow rate of 10 L/ min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO 2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.
  • ➤ In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Automated External Defibrillator

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Automated External Defibrillator (AED):
  • • Automated External Defibrillator (AED):
  • • Definition: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses the life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and is able to treat them through defibrillation, the application of electricity which stops the arrhythmia, allowing the heart to re-establish an effective rhythm.
  • • Definition: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses the life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and is able to treat them through defibrillation, the application of electricity which stops the arrhythmia, allowing the heart to re-establish an effective rhythm.
  • • Definition:
  • • Rapid Defibrillation: Rapid defibrillation is paramount in improving survival rates from sudden cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.
  • • Rapid Defibrillation: Rapid defibrillation is paramount in improving survival rates from sudden cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.
  • • Rapid Defibrillation:
  • • User-Friendly and Accessible: AEDs are made for laypersons and first responders, not just for medical professionals. They come with voice prompts and sometimes visual displays to guide the user through each step of the defibrillation process. This design makes it possible for people without extensive medical training to assist in a cardiac emergency.
  • • User-Friendly and Accessible: AEDs are made for laypersons and first responders, not just for medical professionals. They come with voice prompts and sometimes visual displays to guide the user through each step of the defibrillation process. This design makes it possible for people without extensive medical training to assist in a cardiac emergency.
  • • User-Friendly and Accessible:
  • • Self-Analyzing: An AED automatically evaluates the heart rhythm of a person in cardiac arrest. If the device detects a shockable rhythm, it will instruct the user to deliver a shock; if not, it will guide the user to continue with CPR or other appropriate interventions. This ensures that shocks are only given when necessary.
  • • Self-Analyzing: An AED automatically evaluates the heart rhythm of a person in cardiac arrest. If the device detects a shockable rhythm, it will instruct the user to deliver a shock; if not, it will guide the user to continue with CPR or other appropriate interventions. This ensures that shocks are only given when necessary.
  • • Self-Analyzing:
  • • Public Availability: Many public places such as airports, gyms, schools, and shopping centers have publicly accessible AEDs. Increasing the availability and visibility of AEDs in public spaces can reduce the time to defibrillation and increase survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.
  • • Public Availability: Many public places such as airports, gyms, schools, and shopping centers have publicly accessible AEDs. Increasing the availability and visibility of AEDs in public spaces can reduce the time to defibrillation and increase survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.
  • • Public Availability:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Automated External Desynchronizer: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.
  • • Option A. Automated External Desynchronizer:
  • • Option C. Automated Electronic Defibrillator: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.
  • • Option C. Automated Electronic Defibrillator:
  • • Option D. Automated External Decompressor: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.
  • • Option D. Automated External Decompressor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is a crucial device for rapidly diagnosing and treating life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias through defibrillation, especially designed for use by laypersons and first responders to increase survival rates in cases of sudden cardiac arrest.
  • ➤ An Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is a crucial device for rapidly diagnosing and treating life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias through defibrillation, especially designed for use by laypersons and first responders to increase survival rates in cases of sudden cardiac arrest.
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg 2537
  • ➤ Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9 th Ed. Pg
  • ➤ 2537

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.
  • • Option A. 5 L/min:
  • • Option B. 15 L/min : This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.
  • • Option B. 15 L/min
  • • Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.
  • • Option D. 20 L/min:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: Addison's disease is commonly associated with: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Autoimmune adrenalitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020) School of fish appearance Bleeds on touch Painful Groove sign
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A, B, & C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by painful ulcers with a friable base that easily bleeds and has a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain. The "groove sign" is not associated with chancroid but rather with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neostigmine is the preferred agent for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a laceration on his arm sustained during a fall. He reports significant pain, and a local anesthetic is planned for wound closure. During the procedure, the patient becomes restless, agitated, and his blood pressure rises to 180/100 mmHg. Upon further questioning, the patient admits to using a substance recreationally that he believes is responsible for his symptoms. Which of the following local anesthetics is most likely causing his hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cocaine is an ester local anesthetic with strong vasoconstrictive properties, leading to hypertension as one of its cardiovascular effects. Cocaine acts as a powerful stimulant of the central nervous system by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, thereby increasing sympathetic tone. This results in vasoconstriction, elevated heart rate, and raised blood pressure. Due to these potent vasoconstrictive effects, cocaine can induce hypertension, even at small doses, making it unique among local anesthetics.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mepivacaine : Mepivacaine is an amide local anesthetic used for regional anesthesia with minimal cardiovascular effects. It does not possess significant vasoconstrictive properties and is unlikely to cause hypertension, making it a safer choice compared to cocaine.
  • • Option A. Mepivacaine
  • • Option B. Prilocaine : Prilocaine is an amide local anesthetic commonly used for regional anesthesia and dental procedures. While it is associated with methemoglobinemia as a potential side effect, it does not have significant vasoconstrictive properties and does not cause hypertension. Prilocaine primarily acts by blocking sodium channels in nerve fibers, reducing nerve signal transmission.
  • • Option B. Prilocaine
  • • Option D. Procaine : Procaine, an ester local anesthetic, has a short duration of action and does not have the same vasoconstrictive or hypertensive effects as cocaine. It is primarily used in minor procedures and is considered relatively safe regarding cardiovascular side effects.
  • • Option D. Procaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cocaine is a local anesthetic that causes hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects and central nervous system stimulation. It works by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, increasing sympathetic activity and blood pressure, distinguishing it from other local anesthetics that lack these effects.

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

Ans. D) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Toluidine blue 'O' and malachite green
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Toluidine blue ‘O’ and malachite green

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Albert stain, which contains Toluidine blue 'O' and Malachite green, is specifically used for staining metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae . These granules are an important diagnostic feature for diphtheria.

questions.text: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side

options.label: B
options.text: Pain and temperature lost on the same side

options.label: C
options.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

options.label: D
options.text: Only pain lost on the same side

questions.correct_answer: C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Brown-Sequard syndrome results from a hemisection (partial transection) of the spinal cord, leading to a distinct pattern of neurological symptoms:
  • • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits : Motor Function : There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia. Proprioception and Discriminative Touch : Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain. Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits : Pain and Temperature Sensation : Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.
  • • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits : Motor Function : There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia. Proprioception and Discriminative Touch : Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits
  • • Motor Function : There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia. Proprioception and Discriminative Touch : Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • • Motor Function : There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
  • • Motor Function
  • • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch : Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch
  • • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits : Pain and Temperature Sensation : Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.
  • • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits
  • • Pain and Temperature Sensation : Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.
  • • Pain and Temperature Sensation : Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.
  • • Pain and Temperature Sensation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side : Incorrect because fine touch is lost on the same side as the lesion, not the opposite.
  • • Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side
  • • Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side : Incorrect as pain and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.
  • • Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side
  • • Option D. Only pain lost on the same side : Incorrect because pain sensation is lost on the opposite side and is associated with temperature loss as well.
  • • Option D. Only pain lost on the same side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemi section of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.
  • ➤ Functions of tracts involved -
  • ➤ Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception
  • ➤ Spinothalamic tract → contralateral pain and temperature sensation
  • ➤ Corticospinal tract → primary motor activity same side of the body.

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)

Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.
  • • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.
  • • Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy:
  • • Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.
  • • Option C. Ovarian cystectomy:
  • • Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.
  • • Option D. Ectopic pregnancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuromyelitis optica should be considered in patients presenting with recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, especially when there is a good response to steroid treatment. Distinguishing NMO from multiple sclerosis is crucial, as treatment and prognosis differ significantly between these conditions.

questions.text: During your clinical rotations, you are reviewing data from an experiment that examined the correlation between Vitamin D levels and diastolic blood pressure (DBP). The experiment aimed to ascertain the variability within two distinct sample sets. Based on the findings, the average DBP was noted to be 110, with an associated standard deviation of 11. Similarly, the mean Vitamin D level was observed to be 18, with a standard deviation of 3. With reference to the coefficient of variation (COV), which statement accurately represents the collected data? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: COV of DBP is more than Vitamin D

options.label: B
options.text: COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

options.label: C
options.text: Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability

options.label: D
options.text: It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.correct_answer: B. COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) COV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The coefficient of variation provides a useful comparison of variability across different datasets. In this case, the higher COV for Vitamin D indicates a greater relative variation compared to DBP, highlighting important considerations for researchers analyzing the impacts or associations involving these variables.
  • ➤ The coefficient of variation provides a useful comparison of variability across different datasets.
  • ➤ In this case, the higher COV for Vitamin D indicates a greater relative variation compared to DBP, highlighting important considerations for researchers analyzing the impacts or associations involving these variables.

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Nephrogenic DI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation in the aquaporin channels, particularly Aquaporin-2, leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition is characterized by an inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine in response to ADH, resulting in the production of large volumes of dilute urine. Understanding the genetic basis of nephrogenic DI is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management, which typically involves addressing the symptoms and managing water intake rather than hormone therapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Diabetes Insipidus/Chapter 381

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of obstructive sleep apnea is scheduled for elective surgery. During the preoperative assessment, the anesthesiologist performs an airway evaluation using the Mallampati classification system. The patient is asked to open her mouth and protrude her tongue without phonating. Based on the visualization of the oral structures, the anesthesiologist classifies her airway as shown in the image. What is the Mallampati classification of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Mallampati classification is a simple and widely used method to predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation by assessing the visibility of the oropharyngeal structures. In a Mallampati class II airway, the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible when the patient opens their mouth and protrudes their tongue. This classification suggests a relatively straightforward intubation but indicates that the airway may still pose some challenges. The image provided in the scenario shows the features characteristic of Mallampati class II, making it the correct classification.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Class I : In a Mallampati class I airway, the hard palate, soft palate, entire uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible. This represents the easiest airway to intubate, with no expected difficulty in visualizing the glottis during intubation.
  • • Option A. Class I
  • • Option C. Class III : A Mallampati class III airway is characterized by the visibility of only the soft palate and the base of the tongue, with the uvula either partially visible or not visible at all. This classification indicates a potentially more difficult intubation.
  • • Option C. Class III
  • • Option D. Class IV : In Mallampati class IV, only the hard palate is visible, with neither the soft palate nor the uvula visible. This suggests a significantly more challenging airway, often requiring advanced airway management techniques.
  • • Option D. Class IV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mallampati classification is a valuable tool for predicting the ease of intubation based on the visibility of the oropharyngeal structures. A Class II classification, where the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible, suggests a moderately easy intubation, but with some potential for difficulty. Understanding this classification helps in planning for airway management during anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.correct_answer: B. Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.
  • • Option A. Jaw Tumor:
  • • Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.
  • • Option B. Dermoid cyst:
  • • Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.
  • • Option D. Sebaceous cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

  • ➤ Deals with rights of patients with mental illness and treatment delivery. Important clauses-

  • ➤ A. Capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision- Every person, including patients with mental illness, are assumed to have it if they can-

  • ➤ How they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness

  • ➤ Independent admissions- When the patient himself wants to get admitted Supported admission (for a maximum of 30 days)- A person who has lost the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions and requires significant support from a nominated representative can be admitted under a “supported admission”

  • ➤ E. Ban on direct ECT

  • ➤ G. Ban on psychosurgery
  • ➤ H. Decriminalisation of suicide attempt - Any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished
  • ➤ I. Restraints and seclusions - A patient can be physically restrained only-

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is undergoing an elective hip replacement surgery. During anesthesia induction, a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant is administered to facilitate intubation and surgical access. Shortly after administration, the patient develops profound muscle relaxation and paralysis without any muscle fasciculations. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the muscle relaxant used in this scenario?

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase at the synaptic cleft

options.label: C
options.text: Competitive inhibition of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.correct_answer: C. Competitive inhibition of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Curare group muscle relaxants, such as atracurium and rocuronium, are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents. These drugs work by competitively binding to acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction without activating them, thereby preventing acetylcholine from binding to these receptors. This inhibition blocks the action of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis and relaxation. Since these agents do not depolarize the muscle membrane, they do not cause initial muscle contractions (fasciculations), making them useful during surgeries requiring controlled muscle relaxation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Direct stimulation of acetylcholine receptors : This mechanism describes the action of depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents like succinylcholine, which initially cause muscle contractions before leading to paralysis. This is not the mechanism of curare group drugs, which are non-depolarizing.
  • • Option A. Direct stimulation of acetylcholine receptors
  • • Option B. Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase at the synaptic cleft : Inhibiting acetylcholinesterase increases acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, enhancing muscle contraction, which is the opposite of muscle relaxation. This action is seen with agents like neostigmine, used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Option B. Inhibition of acetylcholinesterase at the synaptic cleft
  • • Option D. Activation of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum : This action describes drugs like dantrolene, which is used to treat malignant hyperthermia by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, thus preventing muscle contraction. It does not describe the mechanism of curare-like drugs.
  • • Option D. Activation of calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Curare group muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing agents that competitively inhibit acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing acetylcholine binding and resulting in muscle paralysis without initial contractions. This mechanism is crucial for inducing controlled muscle relaxation during surgical procedures.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome
  • • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
  • • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
  • • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Testicular atrophy : Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.
  • • Option B. Testicular atrophy
  • • Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm : Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.
  • • Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm
  • • Option D. Orchitis : Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.
  • • Option D. Orchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Proprioception

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Proprioception refers to the sense of the relative position of body parts and the strength of effort being employed in movement. It provides the brain with information about limb position, movement, and force. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Temperature : Temperature sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive differences in external and internal temperatures.
  • • Option A
  • • Temperature
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve : The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve : The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve
  • • Option B . Pain : Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.
  • • Option B
  • • Pain
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve : The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve : The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve
  • • Option C . Touch : Touch or tactile sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive pressure or contact with the skin.
  • • Option C
  • • Touch
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve : Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve : Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.
  • • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 antigen on B-cells, making it effective in treating B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The specificity of rituximab for CD20 allows it to selectively destroy B-cells, providing therapeutic benefits in these conditions.

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.correct_answer: A. Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy
  • ➤ Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy
  • ➤ Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit
  • ➤ Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: All of the following can cause miosis except
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Belladonna

References:

  • ↳ Reference: KDT 8 th /115,122,127,499

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of HIV is started on combined active antiretroviral therapy (cART). After few months of treatment, he develops palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation. What is the most likely drug implicated in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Emtricitabine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emtricitabine, an NRTI used in the treatment of HIV, is known to cause palmo-plantar hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This differentiates it from other antiretroviral medications such as nelfinavir, abacavir, and zidovudine, which have different side effect profiles.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.
